subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Serve the pasta with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper on top.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
materials: Bacon, visually described as strips of pork meat
outcomes: Crispy bacon, visually described as browned and crunchy pieces of bacon
tools: Knife, visually described as a sharp cutting tool
Frying pan, visually described as a flat-bottomed pan for cooking
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into pieces and cook it in a frying pan until it becomes crispy. Once cooked, set aside some of the crispy bacon pieces for garnish and drain the excess fat from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon is cooked until crispy to add texture and flavor to the dish. Setting aside some bacon for garnish enhances the presentation.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is cooked evenly by stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon, as it can become too hard and lose its flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-2
materials: Whole eggs (visual: whole eggs in a bowl)
outcomes: Egg mixture ready for carbonara (visual: creamy egg mixture with cheese and pepper)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate the egg yolks from the whites using your thumb or by passing the yolk back and forth between shell halves. Whisk the egg yolks together with whole eggs. Grate cheese into the egg mixture and add black pepper. Mix until the consistency resembles Cadbury cream egg filling.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The egg mixture forms the base of the carbonara sauce, providing richness and creaminess when combined with the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the 'hold the yolk with your thumb' trick or the 'back and forth' method to separate egg yolks easily.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to accidentally use egg yolkles, as it can ruin the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-3
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin pasta used as the main ingredient.
Salt: White crystalline substance used to season the water.
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked until al dente: Firm to the bite, not too soft, and ready to be mixed with the sauce.
Reserved pasta water: Starchy water saved for use in the sauce to help it emulsify and become creamy.
tools: Pot: Large container used to boil water and cook spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot, add salt to the boiling water, and then add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente. Reserve some of the pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding pasta water to the sauce is to help emulsify the sauce and make it creamy. The starch in the pasta water helps bind the sauce ingredients together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the spaghetti initially after adding it to the boiling water to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Breaking spaghetti in half is considered a culinary crime in Italy and can ruin the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
materials: Bacon, visually described as strips of pork meat
outcomes: Crispy bacon, visually described as browned and crunchy pieces of bacon
tools: Knife, visually described as a sharp cutting tool
Frying pan, visually described as a flat-bottomed pan for cooking
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into pieces and cook it in a frying pan until it becomes crispy. Once crispy, set aside some pieces for garnish and drain the excess fat from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon is cooked until crispy to add texture and flavor to the dish. Setting aside some crispy bacon for garnish enhances the presentation and taste of the final dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is cooked evenly by stirring occasionally to prevent burning and achieve a uniform crispiness.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon, as it can become too hard and lose its flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-5
materials: Pasta water, which is the water used to cook the spaghetti, reserved for mixing with the egg mixture.
Egg mixture, which includes egg yolks and grated pecorino romano cheese, mixed together to form a creamy base.
Spaghetti, cooked and ready to be combined with the sauce.
Bacon, cooked and used as part of the sauce.
outcomes: A creamy sauce that coats the spaghetti, achieved by mixing the pasta water with the egg mixture and combining it with the bacon and spaghetti.
tools: Pan, used to cook the bacon and mix the spaghetti with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: First, add a bit of pasta water into the egg mixture to help melt the cheese. Then, transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the pan with the bacon. Mix them together. Add the egg mixture to the pan, allowing the heat from the noodles to cook the egg slightly and create a creamy sauce. You can put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce if needed. Add more pasta water to achieve the desired creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is added to the egg mixture to help melt the cheese and create a creamy texture. The heat from the noodles is sufficient to cook the egg mixture slightly, forming a sauce without scrambling the eggs. Adding more pasta water helps achieve the desired creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce. This helps achieve the creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon and pan have cooled slightly before adding the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling. The pan can be put on low heat to thicken the sauce, but be cautious not to overheat.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-3
materials: Spaghetti: Straight, parallel line spaghetti used for cooking.
Salt: Used to salt the boiling water for cooking spaghetti.
outcomes: Cooked spaghetti: Spaghetti cooked until al dente, ready to be mixed with sauce.
Reserved pasta water: Some pasta water set aside for use in the sauce.
tools: Pot: Used to boil water and cook spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot, add salt to the boiling water, and then add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding pasta water to the sauce is to help with the melting of cheese and to make the sauce creamy. Additionally, pasta water can be used to adjust the sauce consistency and prevent the dish from becoming too dry.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the spaghetti initially after adding it to the boiling water to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Breaking spaghetti in half is considered a culinary crime in Italy and can ruin the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-5
materials: Egg yolk mixture (egg yolks and pecorino romano)
outcomes: A creamy sauce that coats the spaghetti
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Mix a bit of pasta water into the egg yolk and pecorino romano mixture to start melting the cheese. Add the cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the pan with the bacon. Combine the spaghetti with the bacon and egg mixture, adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water helps melt the cheese and create a creamy sauce. The heat from the noodles cooks the egg just enough to thicken the sauce without scrambling it.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon pan is cool enough before adding the egg mixture to avoid overcooking the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve Pasta-8
materials: Pecorino or Parmesan cheese: Grated cheese used as a garnish on the pasta.
Black pepper: Freshly ground black pepper added as a garnish.
Crispy bacon: Cooked bacon pieces used as a garnish.
outcomes: Pasta is served with additional cheese, black pepper, and crispy bacon garnish, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the pasta by adding some pepper, more pecorino or parmesan cheese, and crispy bacon as garnish before serving.

metadata.title: Not Spaghetti Carbonara - You Suck at Cooking (episode 138)

subtitles.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
It's so simple!
Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.
Let's not waste any time, now let's go!
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.
So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon.
And thick cut bacon would be best.
You could also use pancetta.
So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.
That's about three quarters of an inch.
Turn this pan on to medium heat.
I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right.
Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan.
And what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy.
We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese.
Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.
I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.

So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.
I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description.
Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up.
So here's all our beautiful cheese.
Okay, now time for the eggs.
A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks.
I like to do a mixture of both.
So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.
The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.
Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.
And you'll see all that, and it looked like so much cheese, right?
But as this breaks down, it won't look like that anymore.
Add that all in.
And so now we have a consistency like this.
Now, this is a very important time for our good friend, Sergeant Gilbert.
I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture.
If you didn't know already, Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper.
He's a sentient being, a pepper grinder, who became selfaware in 2020.
You know, and this is preference.
Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.
As you can see, there's a lot of fat coming out of this bacon.
Just want to turn this occasionally.
And we are going to be using some, but not all of this fat in the actual spaghetti carbonara.
Another thing you can do is just take a little bit of that boiling water and add it to the eggs.
Quickly whisk that in.
We're kind of equalizing the temperatures here and loosening up this egg mixture a little bit, and it's going to make the whole pasta come together a lot easier in the end.
I put just about a quarter cup in here.
Our bacon is almost rendered, so now we'll drop our spaghetti.
We'll try to do that twisty thing.
Kind of worked.
Just get a little bit of water up on it.
Let that roll.
Check it on the bacon.
I turned the heat down in the end.
Be careful not to overcook this.
Looks pretty much perfect.
First, I'm going to take some out for garnish.
Drain it on a paper towel.
Now I'm turning off the heat of this pan, and I'm going to drain off most of the fat, all except for about two tablespoons or so.
And then just set that back over there.
Remember, now, heat is off.
This is so important.
Okay, and of course, we're going to put some olive oil in this pasta.
No, we're not going to do that.
Why do people do that?
It's a myth.
It's a myth.
Just like MSG is going to give you cancer or whatever.
It's just not true, and it serves no purpose.
So don't do it.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Reserve some pasta water and drain the spaghetti.
Add the drained spaghetti to the pan with bacon fat (heat still off).
Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with more grated Parmigiano Reggiano and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Bacon is crispy and some is set aside for garnish
Excess fat is drained from the bacon
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into thick slices, about three-quarters of an inch. Heat a pan on medium and add a tiny bit of olive oil if desired. Place the bacon in the pan and cook it slowly to render out the fat and make it crispy. Once crispy, set aside some bacon for garnish and drain it on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain most of the fat from the pan, leaving about two tablespoons.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy without burning. Setting aside some bacon for garnish adds texture and flavor to the final dish. Draining excess fat prevents the dish from becoming too greasy.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Using thick cut bacon will yield better texture and flavor. Adding a tiny bit of olive oil can help start the rendering process, although it's not traditional.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon as it can become too hard and lose its flavor. Ensure to drain most of the fat to avoid a greasy dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to al dente
Reserved pasta water for later use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Reserve the pasta water for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is reserved because it will be used later to help emulsify the sauce and adjust the consistency of the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to handle the spaghetti easily when transferring it from the pot.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti; it should be slightly al dente as it will continue to cook when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcomes: A well-mixed egg and cheese mixture with a creamy consistency, seasoned with black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate two egg yolks from the whites. Combine the two egg yolks with three whole eggs in a bowl. Whisk the eggs together. Gradually whisk in the grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses until well combined. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it into the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The mixture of whole eggs and egg yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. The cheese adds flavor and helps create a creamy texture. The black pepper adds a bit of spice and depth to the flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: You can adjust the amount of black pepper according to your taste preference.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing with the cheese and pepper.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Crispy bacon pieces for the pasta and garnish
Excess bacon fat drained, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into thick slices, about three-quarters of an inch. Heat a pan on medium and add a tiny bit of olive oil if desired. Place the bacon in the pan and cook it slowly to render out the fat and make it crispy. Once crispy, set aside some bacon pieces for garnish and drain them on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain most of the bacon fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy, which is desirable for both the pasta and as a garnish. Leaving some fat in the pan will help emulsify the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick cut bacon for better texture. Adding a tiny bit of olive oil can help with cooking, although it's not traditional.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon to avoid burning it. Ensure the heat is turned off before draining the fat to prevent any accidents.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to al dente
Reserved pasta water for later use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Reserve the pasta water for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is reserved because it will be used later to help emulsify the sauce and adjust the consistency of the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti from the pot to the pan, as it helps in handling the pasta gently without breaking it.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti; it should be slightly al dente as it will continue to cook slightly when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
outcomes: A creamy sauce that coats the spaghetti without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the spaghetti is cooked al dente, use tongs to transfer it to the pan with the bacon fat. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti. Gently mix to combine, ensuring the eggs do not scramble. The heat from the pasta will cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The eggs are cooked by the residual heat from the pasta, which prevents them from scrambling and creates a creamy sauce. Adding pasta water can help emulsify the sauce and adjust its consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it and achieve the desired creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing them with the hot pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve Pasta-7
outcomes: Pasta Carbonara served with additional cheese, black pepper, and crispy bacon garnish, ready to eat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Plate the pasta using tongs. Sprinkle additional Parmigiano Reggiano cheese over the pasta. Add crispy bacon pieces on top for garnish. Optionally, add more freshly ground black pepper to taste.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding more cheese and bacon on top enhances the flavor and texture, providing a creamy and crunchy contrast that is appealing.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is crispy for a satisfying crunch when used as a garnish.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be gentle when plating the pasta to avoid breaking it.

metadata.title: Pasta Carbonara the American Way (With Bacon)

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop and cook the bacon until crispy, then set aside some for garnish and drain excess fat.
original_steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Separate egg yolks, whisk with whole eggs, and mix with grated cheese and black pepper.
original_steps: In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Spaghetti
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente, reserving some pasta water.
original_steps: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water and drain the spaghetti.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix pasta water with egg mixture, then combine spaghetti with bacon and egg mixture to create a creamy sauce.
original_steps: Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Add the drained spaghetti to the pan with bacon fat (heat still off).
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.

subgoal_definitions.title: Serve Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Serve the pasta with additional cheese, black pepper, and crispy bacon garnish.
original_steps: Plate the pasta and garnish with more grated Parmigiano Reggiano and crispy bacon.
Serve the pasta with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper on top.
